{{URL|http://tiruppur.tn.nic.in/#}} | footnotes = | official_name = }} '''Tiruppur''' or '''Tirupur''' ({{IPA-ta|t̪ɪɾɨppuːr|}} {{audio|Tirupur.ogg}}) is a city located in the [[Kongunadu]] region, [[India]]n state of [[Tamil Nadu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiruppurcorp.tn.gov.in/index.html|title=About Tirupur Corporation|access-date=15 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090222182132/http://tiruppurcorp.tn.gov.in/index.html|archive-date=22 February 2009|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Tiruppur is the administrative headquarters of [[Tiruppur district]] and the [[List of cities in Tamil Nadu by population|fifth largest]] [[urban agglomeration]] in [[Tamil Nadu]]. Located on the banks of [[Noyyal River]], it has been ruled at different times, by the [[Early Pandyan Kingdom|Early Pandyas]], [[Medieval Cholas]], [[Later Cholas]], [[Mysore Kingdom]] and the [[British Raj|British]]. It is situated at the centre of the South Indian [[Peninsula]], about {{convert|450|km|mi|0}} southwest of the state capital [[Chennai]] about {{convert|50|km|mi|0}} east of [[Coimbatore]] and {{convert|50|km|mi|0}} south of [[Erode]].
Tiruppur is administered by [[Tiruppur Municipal Corporation|municipal corporation]] which was established in 2008 and the total area of the corporation is 159.6 km<sup>2</sup> divided into 60 wards. The total population of the city as per the 2011 census is 444,352. Thiruppur is a part of the [[Tiruppur (Lok Sabha constituency)|Tiruppur constituency]] that elects its member of parliament.
Tiruppur is a major textile and knit wear hub contributing to 90% of total cotton knit wear exports from India.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fairwear.org/ul/cms/fck-uploaded/documents/companies/CountryStudies/indiatirupurnew-developmentsfwfcountrystudy.pdf|title=The New Developments in Tirupur|publisher=Fairwear Foundation|access-date=2 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150921223727/http://www.fairwear.org/ul/cms/fck-uploaded/documents/companies/CountryStudies/indiatirupurnew-developmentsfwfcountrystudy.pdf|archive-date=21 September 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The textile industry provides employment to over six [[lakh]] people and contributed to exports worth {{INRConvert|200|b}} in 2014-15.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-04-12/news/61066308_1_knitwear-exports-cent-interest-subvention-textile-hub-tirupur|title=Knitwear exports from Tirupur cross Rs 20,000 crore|publisher=The Economic Times|access-date=2 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150602231429/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2015-04-12/news/61066308_1_knitwear-exports-cent-interest-subvention-textile-hub-tirupur|archive-date=2 June 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiacatalog.com/cityguide/tirupur.html|title=City Guide: Tirupur|publisher=India Catalog.Com|access-date=24 September 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713024927/http://www.indiacatalog.com/cityguide/tirupur.html|archive-date=13 July 2011|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Etymology== The name Thiruppur is said to have emerged during the [[Mahabharata]] era. According to legends, the cattle herds of [[Pandavas]] were stolen by thieves and the same was recaptured by [[Arjuna]]'s forces resulting in the name "Thiruppur" (Thiruppu : to turn and oor : place in [[Tamil language|Tamil]]) meaning "place where they were returned back".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ecourts.gov.in/tn/tiruppur|title=History of Tiruppur|publisher=Government of India|access-date=2 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603000134/http://ecourts.gov.in/tn/tiruppur|archive-date=3 June 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==History== Thiruppur formed a part of the [[Kongu Nadu]] region ruled by the [[Chera Dynasty|Cheras]] during [[Sangam period]].<ref name="Trade">{{cite news|last=Subramanian|first=T. banks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiruppur.nic.in/rivers.html|title=Rivers of Tiruppur|publisher=Government of Tamil Nadu|access-date=6 September news|last=Vanavarayar|first=Shankar|title=Scripting history|url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2010/06/21/stories/2010062151120400.htm|accessdate=9 May 2011|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=21 June name="Cholaroad">{{cite news|last=M|first=Soundariya Preetha|title=Tale of an ancient road|url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/06/30/stories/2007063054660500.htm|accessdate=9 May 2011|date=30 June 2012|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The region came under the rule of the [[Vijayanagara Empire]] by the 15th century and later [[Polygar|Palayakkarars]], the chieftains of [[Madurai Nayaks]] ruled the region.<ref>{{cite news|title=The land called Kongunadu|url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2005/11/19/stories/2005111902090200.htm|accessdate=9 June 2010|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|date=19 November 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110528171005/http://www.hindu.com/mp/2005/11/19/stories/2005111902090200.htm|archive-date=28 May 2011|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the later part of the 18th century, the region came under the [[Kingdom of Mysore]], following a series of wars with the [[Madurai Nayak Dynasty]]. After the [[Siege of Coimbatore|defeat]] of [[Tipu Sultan]] in the [[Anglo-Mysore Wars]], the [[British East India Company]] annexed the region into the [[Madras Presidency]] in 1799.
Thirupur was an [[agriculture|agricultural]] town with irrigated farms and the farmers became small owners of various textile related units during the 1970s. The boom in the [[textile]] industry led to an inter woven network of the small scale units leading to growth of the city into a major textile hub.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tiruppur.com/history.htm|title=History of Tiruppur|publisher=tiruppur.com|access-date=6 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903031554/http://www.tiruppur.com/history.htm|archive-date=3 September 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Tiruppur Municipal Corporation|Thiruppur]] became a [[municipal corporation]] in 2008 and a separate [[Tiruppur district]] was carved out from parts of [[Coimbatore district]] and [[Erode district]] in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiruppur.nic.in/distformation.html|title=Tiruppur district formation|publisher=Government of Tamil Nadu|access-date=6 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304040548/http://tiruppur.nic.in/distformation.html|archive-date=4 March 2016|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Geography== Thiruppur is located at {{Coord|11.1075|N|77.3398|E|}} on the banks of the [[Noyyal River]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IN/25/Tiruppur.html |title=Falling Rain Genomics, Inc - Tiruppur |publisher=Fallingrain.com |access-date=24 September 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100415153801/http://www.fallingrain.com/world/IN/25/Tiruppur.html |archive-date=15 April 2010 |url-status=live |df=dmy-all }}</ref> It has an average elevation of 295 metres (967 feet) and covers an area of {{convert|159.6|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}.<ref name="area"/>

[[Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes]] accounted for 5.47% and .06% of the population respectively. The average literacy of the city was 78.17%, compared to the national average of 72.99%.<ref name="dashboard"/> The city had a total of 124,617 households. There were a total of 207,358 workers, comprising 490 cultivators, 721 main agricultural labourers, 3,492 in house hold industries, 191,882 other workers, 10,773 marginal workers, 89 marginal cultivators, 74 marginal agricultural labourers, 470 marginal workers in household industries and 10,140 other marginal workers.<ref name=2011census>{{cite web|title=Census Info 2011 Final population totals - Tiruppur(05904)|url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/pca/SearchDetails.aspx?Id=707472|publisher=Office of The Registrar General and Census Commissioner, Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India|year=2013|access-date=26 Jan 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924150650/http://www.censusindia.gov.in/pca/SearchDetails.aspx?Id=707472|archive-date=24 September 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The area of Tiruppur was expanded in 2011 and the population was 877,778 as per the revised estimate.<ref name="Smart"/>
As per the religious census of 2011, Thiruppur (M Corp.) had 86.05% [[Hindus]], 10.36% [[Muslims]], 3.33% [[Christians]], 0.03% [[Sikhs]], 0.01% [[Buddhists]], 0.07% [[Jainism|Jains]], 0.14% following other religions and 0.01% following no religion or did not indicate any religious preference.<ref name=religion2011>{{cite web|title=Population By Religious Community - Tamil Nadu|year=2011|url=http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/C-01.html|format=XLS|publisher=Office of The Registrar General and Census Commissioner, Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India|accessdate=13 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913045700/http://www.censusindia.gov.in/2011census/C-01.html|archive-date=13 September 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Climate== The climate in Thiruppur is tropical with the mean maximum and minimum temperatures varying between {{convert|35|to|22|°C|°F}}. The summer occurs during the months March, April and May when the weather is hot and dry. The maximum temperature during the summer months will be around {{convert|35|°C|°F}} and the minimum temperature will be around {{convert|29|°C|°F}}. The monsoon months are the months of June, July and August. These months are mainly characterised by mild showers and a reduced temperature. The post monsoon or winter months are September, October, November, December and January. These months generally have a cool climate and temperatures rarely rise beyond a maximum of around {{convert|29|°C|°F}}. The minimum temperature during this season will be around {{convert|24|°C|°F}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mustseeindia.com/Tirupur-weather|title=Overview|accessdate=11 December 2010|publisher=Must see India|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713195940/http://www.mustseeindia.com/Tirupur-weather|archive-date=13 July 2010|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Due to the presence of the [[Palghat gap]], the city receives rainfall from the [[South-west monsoon]] in the months from June to August. After a humid September, the [[North-east monsoon]] brings rains starts from October which lasts till early November. The average annual rainfall is around {{convert|700|mm|abbr=on}} with the North East and the South West monsoons contributing to 47% and 28% respectively to the total rainfall. The soil is predominantly black, which is suitable for cotton cultivation, but it also has some red loamy soil. Tirupur falls under the Class III/IV [[Earthquake hazard zoning of India|seismic zone]], having experienced a 6.0 [[Richter magnitude scale|Richter scale]] earthquake in 1900.

Thiruppur Municipality was established in 1917 and was upgraded to a municipal corporation in 2008. The city is divided into 60 wards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tiruppuronline.in/city-guide/local-bodies-in-tirupur|title=Local bodies in Tirupur|access-date=6 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905210252/http://www.tiruppuronline.in/city-guide/local-bodies-in-tirupur|archive-date=5 September 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Each ward is represented by a councillor who is elected by direct election and the [[mayor of Tiruppur]] is elected by councillors. The executive wing of the corporation is headed by a corporation commissioner and maintains basic services like water supply, sewage and roads. Law and order is maintained by Thiruppur police headed by a police commissioner of [[Deputy inspector general of police|Deputy Inspector General]] rank. The city police has 7 police stations, 3 traffic police stations and over 1000 personnel.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/coimbatore/Tirupur-city-to-have-its-own-police-commissioner-from-September-15/articleshow/22355263.cms|title=Tiruppur to have its own police commissioner|newspaper=[[Times of India]]|date=6 September 2013|access-date=6 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003095331/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/coimbatore/Tirupur-city-to-have-its-own-police-commissioner-from-September-15/articleshow/22355263.cms|archive-date=3 October 2016|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The Thiruppur District Court is the ultimate judicial authority in the district.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ecourts.gov.in/tn/tiruppur|title=Tiruppur courts|publisher=ecourts.gov.in|access-date=6 September 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909234828/http://ecourts.gov.in/tn/tiruppur|archive-date=9 September 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Thirupur has two assembly constituencies [[Tiruppur North (State Assembly Constituency)|Thiruppur North]] and [[Tiruppur South (State Assembly Constituency)|Thiruppur South]]. Thiruppur is part of [[Tirupur (Lok Sabha constituency)|Thirupur Lok Sabha constituency]] which was created during the delimination in 2008 consisting parts of erstwhile [[Coimbatore (Lok Sabha constituency)|Coimbatore]], [[Gobichettipalayam (Lok Sabha constituency)|Gobichettipalayam]] and [[Palani (Lok Sabha constituency)|Palani]] constituencies.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://archive.eci.gov.in/se2001/background/S22/TN_ACPC.pdf| format = PDF| title = List of Parliamentary and Assembly Constituencies| access-date = 11 October 2008| location = Tamil Nadu| publisher = Election Commission of India| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090304010951/http://archive.eci.gov.in/se2001/background/S22/TN_ACPC.pdf| archive-date = 4 March 2009| url-status = dead| df = dmy-all}}</ref>
==Economy== Thiruppur is also known as the ''knitwear capital'' of India, accounting for 90% of India's cotton knitwear export.<ref name="dcmsme.gov.in">{{cite web|title=Brief Industrial Profile of Tiruppur district|url=http://dcmsme.gov.in/dips/IPS%20Tiruppur%202012.pdf|website=DCMSME|publisher=Ministry of Micro, Small & Medium Industries, Government of India|access-date=3 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304101505/http://dcmsme.gov.in/dips/IPS%20Tiruppur%202012.pdf|archive-date=4 March 2016|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It has spurred up the textile industry in India for the past three decades. It contributes to a huge amount of foreign exchange in India. In the Fiscal year 2013, exports were {{Indian Rupees}}17,500.<ref name="The Economic Times">{{cite news|title=Textile hub Tiruppur back on resurgence path|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-11-22/news/56362171_1_tirupur-exporters-association-garment-export-hub-crore|accessdate=3 May 2015|work=The Economic Times|date=22 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141230185515/http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2014-11-22/news/56362171_1_tirupur-exporters-association-garment-export-hub-crore|archive-date=30 December 2014|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The city provides employment to around 400,000 workers, with the average salary per worker being around {{Indian Rupees}} 9,000 per month.<ref name="The Economic Times"/>
Special Industrial Parks have been developed to support the textile industry. Nethaji Apparel Park, Thirupur Export Knitwear Industrial Complex, SIDCO Industrial Estate and J.S.Apparel Park are a few that are operational. ==Welfare== Thiruppur has a good educational infrastructure. The city itself has only a few engineering colleges, but the proximal areas and nearby cities of Coimbatore and Erode augurs well. There are 7 Government hospitals at the taluk level with a total number of 896 beds and a total of 43 Primary Health Centers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Department of Public Health & Preventive Medicine|url=http://www.tnhealth.org/dph/dphpm.php|website=www.tnhealth.org|publisher=Tamil Nadu Government|access-date=3 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702012435/http://www.tnhealth.org/dph/dphpm.php|archive-date=2 July 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> in the rural areas<ref>{{cite web|title=List of Government Hospitals|url=http://tiruppur.tn.nic.in/hospitals.html|website=tiruppur.tn.nic.in|publisher=Tamil Nadu Government|access-date=3 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150305004559/http://www.tiruppur.tn.nic.in/hospitals.html|archive-date=5 March 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=List of Private Hospitals|url=http://tiruppur.tn.nic.in/HospitalPhoneNo.html|website=tiruppur.tn.nic.in|publisher=Tamil Nadu Government|access-date=3 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617214956/http://tiruppur.tn.nic.in/Hospitalphoneno.html|archive-date=17 June 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
;Environmental issues Thiruppur, like any other industrial town, faces its share of environmental pollution complaints.<ref>{{cite web|title=None|url=http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydispfree.aspx?filename=39737|website=The Judgement Information System|publisher=High Court of Madras|access-date=3 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150531103649/http://judis.nic.in/judis_chennai/qrydispfree.aspx?filename=39737|archive-date=31 May 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=None|url=http://indiankanoon.org/doc/197754/|website=www.indiankanoon.org|accessdate=3 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411165929/http://indiankanoon.org/doc/197754/|archive-date=11 April 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> As per the directive of Madras High Court,<ref>{{cite news|title=Tirupur knitwear cluster asked to abide by court directives on pollution|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/tirupur-knitwear-cluster-asked-to-abide-by-court-directives-on-pollution/article3644610.ece|accessdate=3 May 2015|work=The Hindu}}</ref> zero liquid discharge (ZLD) should be strictly followed in Tiruppur knitwear cluster during the effluent treatment process. Failure to implement this order, led to a court ordered closure of all dyeing units and bleaching units.<ref>{{cite news|title=Along the banks of Noyyal, farmers in grief|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/coimbatore/Along-the-banks-of-Noyyal-farmers-in-grief/articleshow/7503194.cms|accessdate=3 May 2015|work=The Times of India|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003081649/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/coimbatore/Along-the-banks-of-Noyyal-farmers-in-grief/articleshow/7503194.cms|archive-date=3 October 2016|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In turn, Tirupur Exporters Association made a representation to the Government that export revenues of {{Indian Rupees}} 11 billion were lost and about 100,000 labourers lost their job due to a closure of dyeing units in Tirupur.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/todays-paper/tp-economy/article1647824.ece|title=dyeing units hailed|work=The Hindu|access-date=15 October 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130801101501/http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/todays-paper/tp-economy/article1647824.ece|archive-date=1 August 2013|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/06/11/stories/2005061113880500.htm|title=Dyeing units asked not to work|work=The Hindu|access-date=15 October 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212235920/http://hindu.com/2005/06/11/stories/2005061113880500.htm|archive-date=12 February 2009|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
As per a report by CRISIL, prepared in February 2011, ensuring Zero Liquid Discharge (ZLD), will primarily affect the operational costs of dyeing and bleaching units, increasing it by 7% to 10%.<ref>{{cite web|title=Discharge norms compliance to impact Tirupur-based textile units|url=http://www.crisil.com/Ratings/Brochureware/News/CRISIL-Ratings_discharge-norms-compli-pr_160211.pdf|website=www.crisil.com|publisher=CRISIL|accessdate=3 May 2015|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Eventually, by complying with the above order, Tiruppur became the first textile cluster in India to achieve Zero Liquid Discharge in their units.<ref>{{cite Business and Management issues of CETP s – Focus on Tanneries & Textiles in ==Transport== The following are the major highways connecting Thiruppur: *[[State Highway 19 (Tamil Nadu)|SH-19]] : [[Palladam]] - Thiruppur - [[Avinashi]] *SH-37 : Thiruppur - [[Dharapuram]] *SH-196/[[State Highway 81 (Tamil Nadu)|SH-81]] : Thiruppur - [[Gobichettipalayam]] *SH-169 : Thiruppur - Somanur *SH-172 : Thiruppur - [[Kangeyam]] * : Tiruppur - [[Udumalpet]] * : Tiruppur - [[Palani]] * : Tiruppur - [[coimbatore]] * : Tiruppur - [[Pollachi]] * : Tiruppur - [[Guruvayur]] * : Tiruppur - [[Chennai]] * : Tiruppur - [[Bangalore]] * : Tiruppur - [[Mettupalayam, Coimbatore|Mettupalayam]] * : Tiruppur - [[Erode]] * : Tiruppur - [[Salem, Tamil Nadu|Salem]]
Thiruppur is well connected by moffusil bus services to all major towns and cities across [[Tamil Nadu]], [[Kerala]], [[Karnataka]] and [[Andhra Pradesh]]. The city has two major bus stands Old bus stand and New Bus stand.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tiruppurcorporation.tn.gov.in/sal_bus.htm|title=Bus Stand|publisher=Tiruppur corporation|access-date=12 October 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425134557/http://tiruppurcorporation.tn.gov.in/sal_bus.htm|archive-date=25 April 2012|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The nearest airport is [[Coimbatore International Airport]] (45 km) which has regular flights<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coimbatorecity.com/index.php?/content/view/90/27/|title=Coimbatore - Fastest Growing City in India|publisher=Coimbatore.com|access-date=26 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224065412/http://www.coimbatorecity.com/index.php?%2Fcontent%2Fview%2F90%2F27%2F|archive-date=24 February 2012|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> from/to various domestic destinations like [[Ahmedabad]], [[Bangalore]], [[Bhubaneswar]], [[Chennai]], [[Delhi]], [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]], [[Visakhapatnam]],[[Tirupati]],[[Kolkata]], [[Kozhikode]], [[Mumbai]], [[Pune]] and international destinations like [[Sharjah (emirate)|Sharjah]] and [[Singapore]]. The [[Tiruppur railway station]] falls on the fully electrified and double tracked [[Erode Junction railway station|Erode]] - [[Coimbatore Junction railway station|Coimbatore]] [[Indian gauge|broad gauge]] line and is well connected by trains.
==Places of interest== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:kumaranmemorial.JPEG|thumb|200px|right|Kumaran memorial - near [[Tiruppur railway station|railway station]]]] --> Major temples in Thiruppur were built during the reign of [[Chola Dynasty|Cholas]] and [[Pandyas]]. Sukreeswarar Temple, is a 10th-century temple situated at the outskirts of Thiruppur is considered one of the four 'Sirpa Sthalangal' in Kongu region. An epigraphic study conducted studies at the temple reported that though the temple was built by [[Pandyas]], different inscriptions state that the place was used by tribals to offer poojas to [[Lingam|'Shivalingam']] as early as 5th century.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/10/01/stories/2009100155010500.htm|title=Sukreeswarar Temple|work=The Hindu|access-date=2 October 2009|location=Chennai, India|date=1 October 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091003011115/http://www.hindu.com/2009/10/01/stories/2009100155010500.htm|archive-date=3 October 2009|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Some of the popular tourist locations outside the city are Sivanmalai, [[Thirumoorthy hills|Thirumoorthy Hills]], Amaravathi Crocodile Farm, Orathuppalayam Dam, Nanjarayan Tank, Koolipalayam wetlands, [[Andipalayam]] lake, Thirumurugan poondi, Konganagiri hill hock temple, Thiruppur Thirupathi temple, Avinashiappar temple and Vazhai Thottathu Ayyankovil.
The Town Hall, new railway over-bridge, [[Tiruppur Kumaran]] memorial, corporation memorial pillar are some of the landmarks in the Thiruppur city.
